ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned how to conduct archival research and strengthened my writing skills. I also learned tons about slavery, obviously.

This course is an amazing overview of the slave trade. I learned so much about the transatlantic trade and slavery outside of the U.S. I loved meeting in the Beinecke every week. This was a great environment to get formal with historical research and utilizing the Beinecke's resources.
Learned to navigate the archives and how to approach historical research.

More insight into the domestic slave trade and slavery in the North and Upper South. 

Skill gained: Ability to handle archival documents and read archival sources.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
strengths: interesting readings/material covered, opportunity to experience the archives, appropriately challenging for a first-year student
weaknesses: readings can be a lot on top of all your other classes, sometimes expectations not clearly outlined (Prof. Rugemer doesn't keep Canvas updated and gives a lot of instructions orally), you're expected to do a lot of work outside of class toward your final but not really told how to go about it.

Strengths- great classroom environment, introduction to primary source research & writing, we covered a lot of topics/materials, and I loved how Prof Rugemer incorporated secondary critiques of sources for broader perspectives
Weaknesses-Prof Rugemer wasn't always aware of upcoming assignments on the syllabus--instructions were often delayed and unclear. Oftentimes readings were very long and we couldn't properly discuss them. I also think the pacing of the assignments was a bit off. We had little to no assignments besides readings, and then it all picked up at once. I think short essays should have begun and ended a bit sooner so we could have gotten feedback on our annotated bibs in a more timely manner.
I think the course could benefit from more structure. A more clear rubric for papers could help students have direction when writing.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I'd only recommend if you're into history and either like to write or want to push yourself to improve your writing this semester.

I would recommend this course! Viewing a new primary source every week was an amazing experience. The contents of this course are so necessary. I think every student at Yale could benefit from learning about the reality and implications of slavery. The reading load is high, much higher than other first-year seminars, but if you're even remotely interested in the topic--take this course! There were also some amazing speakers, this was an amazing introduction to Yale.

I would highly recommend this course. I think it was exciting, it was engaging, and it was important. It was the course I was most likely to talk about with someone who asked about the courses I was taking last semester.
Yes, its a great introduction to Yale especially for prospective social science/humanities majors. The workload is doable and the class is really engaging and hands on.
